instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_LEFT: What is HALL_SENSOR_LEFT? HALL_SENSOR_LEFT is a signal from the hall sensor on the left side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT: What is HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT? HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT is a signal from the hall sensor on the RIGHT side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20v only turn on with charger
threads.message:
with out battery i get 19.7v  and it goes up to 1.20a i get fan spin for 7 seconds then 19.9v oA i press power button and it does all over again
with battery 19.7 2.10A and it turns on everything works battery charging i can unplug charger everything ok if i close lid and open screen will not come on the keyboard
still light up i hear keys being press i press power button will not shut off
 i test <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
I TRIED WORKING SCREEN
I PUT ANOTHER board in and everything works

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20v only turn on with charger
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT signals, when the problem appears.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20v only turn on with charger
threads.message:
when screen is on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> is 1.4v and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> is 3.5v
when screen is off  <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> is 1.6v and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> is 3.5v 
when the screen is on i put a magnet to J5260 the <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_RIGHT</SIGNAL> AND IT TURNS OFF
when i do the same to J5250 the <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_LEFT</SIGNAL>  it doesn't  TURNS OFF

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20v only turn on with charger
threads.message:
So you have problems with left sensor (J5250); you should change it.
A fast workaround is removing <RESISTOR>R5252</RESISTOR> and joining pins 1/2 of <CHIP>U5255</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 20v only turn on with charger
threads.message: i replace the sensor   AND IT WORKS THANK
